Player controls [b]char[/b] thanks to the default controls of its own [i][b]TileMovement[/b][/i] behavior.

Multiple [b]guard[/b] instances travel their own patrol [b]waypoint[/b] network.
Each [b]guard[/b] instance has its own [i]state[/i] instance variable.
The value of this instance variables help setting a logical state where the instance acts a certain way, according to certain rules specific to when this instance is in this state.

When a [b]guard[/b] sees [b]char[/b] (thanks to the [i][b]LineOfSight[/b][/i] behavior) they switch their "patrol" [i]state[/i] instance variable value to "aggro".
They switch from using the [i][b]TileMovement[/b][/i] behavior for their patrolling movement to the [i][b]PathFinding[/b][/i] behavior for their chasing movement.
They find and move along a path to the position where they last saw [b]char[/b].
Arrived there, they check whether they see [b]char[/b] (and then another "chase" sequence starts) or not.
If they don't see it, a path is calculated to the next [b]waypoint[/b] they are supposed to patrol. Their [i]state[/i] value switches to "back".
Once arrived "back" they switch back to regular "patrol".

List of [b]guard[/b] states :
[item]"patrol" - [b]guard[/b] will travel from a [b]waypoint[/b] to another, according to the values of instance variables from the [b]waypoint[/b] and the [b]guard[/b] object (numbers that will identify the order in which [b]guard[/b] is supposed to reach through all the [b]waypoint[/b] instances for its own course).
[item]"aggro" - [b]guard[/b] has seen [b]char[/b], tries to find a path to the position with the [i][b]PathFinding[/b][/i] behavior. (On path found [i]state[/i] changes to "chase", on failure to find path, [i]state[/i] reverts to "patrol")
[item]"chase" - [b]guard[/b] has found a path to the position of [b]char[/b] it is currently moving to this position.
[item]"search" - [b]guard[/b] has reached the last seen position of [b]char[/b]. [b]guard[/b] moves on itself in hope to see [b]char[/b]. If [b]guard[/b] sees char, it goes into a new chase sequence. If it doesn't when the [i][b]Timer[/b][/i] "guardSearch" triggers (1 second) then it switches [i]state[/i] to "back". 
[item]"back" - [b]guard[/b] moves along a calculated a path to go back to the next [b]waypoint[/b] it should patrol.

[b]guard[/b] [b]visionCone[/b]
function that will draw the vision cone for the given [b]guard[/b], in [b]visionCone[/b] (a [b]DrawingCanvas[/b] object)

children.text:
The idea here is, to draw a cone (in yellow/brown/red color, accordingly to the current state of given [b]guard[/b]
Then, for each [b]wall[/b] that is overlapping this drawn cone, remove the area of [b]wall[/b] as well as the projected line of sight, to let the player know if [b]char[/b] can be seen or not.

In order to determine the "area of sight" to remove, we loop through each [b]wall[/b]. The four points that compose its shape are ordered by distance from [b]guard[/b] (closer distance to further distance).
Then we know we can draw a poly composed by the points of the [b]wall[/b] and projected points at the angle sight.

children.name: lengthMod
children.comment: additional length in order to make sure the "removed" area of vision clears any trace of the drawn cone

children.text: the angle of the cone relies on the value [b]guard[/b].[i][b]LineOfSight[/b][/i].[i]ConeOfView[/i]. We take half of that value and draw a cone around the current angle of [b]guard[/b]

actions.text:
[b]guard[/b].[b][i]LineOfSight[/i][/b].[i]Range[/i] determine the "length" of the vision cone.
Due to the specifics coordinates of the [b]DrawingCanvas[/b] we use [b]visionCone[/b].[i]midX[/i] and .[i]midY[/i] as a starting point where to position the next polygon point from.

We use arrays to temporary store and sort the distance between each points of [b]wall[/b] and [b]guard[/b]

[b]aOrder[/b] array is filled with the values from [b]aPoints[/b].
[b]aPoints[/b] will keep the values for now, [b]aOrder[/b] will be used to sort the values and determine the order in which to draw the polygon

if [b]wall[/b] is not at the exact X or Y of [b]guard[/b] (not exactly on top, to the right, at the bottom, or left from [b]guard[/b]), place polygon points in that order :

Point 2
